programme.title: Judgment With Ashleigh Banfield
programme.desc: Rabbi Fred Neulander was a pillar of his Cherry Hill, New Jersey community - the founder of a synagogue, a father and a husband. Little did anyone know, he was also an adulterer, one capable of hiring a hitman to murder his own wife.

programme.title: Judgment With Ashleigh Banfield
programme.desc: Melanie McGuire made a living bringing life into the world as a fertility clinic nurse; the police accused her of shooting her husband, dismembering his body and disposing of it in suitcases dumped into the Chesapeake Bay.

programme.title: Judgment With Ashleigh Banfield
programme.desc: Rutgers freshman Tyler Clementi and Dharun Ravi had only been roommates for few weeks when Ravi decided to secretly film Tyler kissing another man; soon after, Clementi took his own life and Ravi faced surprising criminal charges.

programme.title: Judgment With Ashleigh Banfield
programme.desc: The murders of Voncile Smith and her sons John and Richard set Pensacola, Florida on edge; the courts try to decide if this was an occult ritual or something much more basic: greed.

programme.title: FL v. Dalia Dippolito
programme.desc: The Defense brought in a reality show expert to try to show jurors a person's motivation in getting their own show. The crew from the show Cops followed Boynton Beach police at the time Dalia was accused of plotting the murder of her husband.

programme.title: FL v. Dalia Dippolito
programme.desc: Dalia Dippolito chooses not to testify in her own defense, as her attorney rests their case-in-chief; she faces three decades in prison if she is convicted of trying to hire a hit man to kill Michael, her husband of six months.

programme.title: FL v. Dalia Dippolito
programme.desc: The judge and both legal teams go over jury instructions and verdict form now that the defense rested their case-in-chief.

programme.title: FL v. Dalia Dippolito
programme.desc: Prosecutors tell jurors that the secretly recorded conversations, fake hit man, staged crime scene and reality TV cameras ended up saving Michael Dippolito's life.

programme.title: FL v. Dalia Dippolito
programme.desc: For the first time in the trial, Dalia Dippolito is seen crying, during the defense's closing argument; she faces a maximum of thirty years if she is convicted for solicitation to commit first degree murder.

programme.title: FL v. Dalia Dippolito
programme.desc: Michael Dippolito was blinded by Dalia's manipulation and fake love, according to prosecutors; they said he trusted and cared for her while she was stealing from him and trying to get him in trouble with police.

programme.title: FL v. Dalia Dippolito
programme.desc: The State continued its rebuttal by pieceing together Dalia Dippolito's actions leading up to the day her husband, Michael, was supposed to be killed.

programme.title: FL v. Dalia Dippolito
programme.desc: All the recorded video and audio clips of Dalia Dippolito seem to show that she had plenty of time to back out of the alleged plot to murder her husband, Michael.

programme.title: Corn Rake Murder Trial
programme.desc: The searches done from Todd Mullis's iPad become a big focus for the jury; those searches include "Women cheat and relationships", "Six traits every cheating woman has" and "Killing unfaithful women".

programme.title: Corn Rake Murder Trial
programme.desc: The investigator who did the deep dive into Todd Mullis' internet searches had more to tell the jury; Travis Hemesath admitted other searches came up, that included some on country singers, Pinterest and the jewelry store, Zales.

programme.title: Corn Rake Murder Trial
programme.desc: Jurors watch more of the police interrogation of Todd Mullis; he claimed early on that her death seemed accidental; prosecutors argue that he killed her, in part, because he did not want to lose his farm in a divorce.

programme.title: Corn Rake Murder Trial
programme.sub-title: No Confession But No Denial Of Murder
programme.desc: The jury hear the last few minutes of his police interview where Todd Mullis talked about the death of his wife, Amy; the defendant didn't confess on the recording, but he did not deny attacking his wife.

programme.title: Corn Rake Murder Trial
programme.desc: Todd Mullis's lawyer tries to prove that he had nothing to do with the murder of his wife, Amy; the defense claims it was an accident; the defendant, Todd Mullis, takes the stand.

programme.title: Corn Rake Murder Trial
programme.desc: Todd Mullis denies killing his wife, Amy, as he testifies in his own murder trial; she had been having an affair with their field manager; her friends claimed she was in fear for her life.

programme.title: Corn Rake Murder Trial
programme.sub-title: I Did Not Kill My Wife
programme.desc: Todd Mullis claims he and his oldest son had been working on the hog farm when Amy fell on a corn rake in a shed before she died; the cross-examination begins on Todd.

programme.title: Suitcase Killer Murder Trial
programme.desc: In opening statements prosecutors alleged the defendant plotted the murder of Bill McGuire, husband of 5 years and father of her two children; the motive -- she wanted to be with a new lover.

programme.title: Suitcase Killer Murder Trial
programme.desc: Lead prosecutor continues opening statements; laying out for jurors the scheme they say the defendant made to get rid of her husband, and then dispose of the his body; Melanie McGuire's defense team delivers its opening statement to jurors.

programme.title: Suitcase Killer Murder Trial
programme.desc: The Defense tells jurors about a fight that Melanie and Bill McGuire had on the same day they purchased their first house; investigators allege that it was on this day that the defendant drugged, killed, and dismembered him.

programme.title: Suitcase Killer Murder Trial
programme.desc: The Defense wraps up its opening statement; Melanie McGuire's attorney wants to show that she had nothing to do with the murder and dismembering of her husband.

programme.title: Suitcase Killer Murder Trial
programme.desc: Jurors listen to more testimony from the police officer from Virginia Beach who recovered the remains of Bill McGuire; prosecutors allege the defendant drugged, killed, and dismembered her husband because she wanted to be with her lover.

programme.title: Judgment With Ashleigh Banfield
programme.desc: As the saying goes, he who represents himself in court has a fool for a client. But in the case of Marc Benayer, who shot a man in his synagogue parking lot, was he a fool, or did his mental illness affect whether the jury would find him guilty?
